citation.article-title: Corynebacterium testudinoris sp. nov., from a tortoise, and Corynebacterium felinum sp. nov., from a Scottish wild cat
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Corynebacterium felinum sp. nov.
Corynebacterium felinum (fe.li«num. L. neut. adj. felinum pertaining to cats)
Cells are Gram-positive, non-motile, non-sporeforming diphtheroids.
Acid is produced from glucose, maltose and ribose but not from lactose, mannitol, sucrose, N-acetyl-β-glucosamine or D-xylose.
Activity is detected for α-glucosidase, pyrazinamidase, pyrrolidonyl arylamidase and leucine arylamidase.

No activity is observed for alkaline phosphatase, acid phosphatase, chymotrypsin, ester lipase C-8, esterase C-4, α-galactosidase, β-galactosidase, β-glucosidase, β-glucuronidase, α-fucosidase, lipase C14, α-mannosidase, phosphoamidase, valine arylamidase or trypsin.
Aesculin, urea and gelatin are not hydrolysed and nitrate is not reduced.
Longchain fatty acids are of the straight-chain saturated and monounsaturated types.
Mycolic acids are present (C32 to C36).
Isolated from a dead Scottish wild cat (Felis sylvestris).

The type strain is M714/95/5T, which has been deposited in the Culture Collection of the University of Göteborg as strain CCUG 3994 and in the Collection of Bacterial Strains of Institut Pasteur as CIP 106740T.
